title: Wednesday, 16th December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Advance notice: this is going to be a short session

PM

We'll be back later for a Fed special

11:02 am
PM

But in the meantime there's precious little to say

PM

And im still ill

PM

and generally feeling sorry for myself

11:02 am
PM

And i have to do a bloody presentation to a load of M&A bankers straight away

PM

And im not prepped for that

PM

Anyway, here's a chart

11:02 am
PM

PM

Fed Funds, effective rate

PM

Flat lined for almost seven years

11:03 am
PM

Where will that end today?

PM

What else is there to say on Yellen?

PM

asks Paul Donovan at UBS

11:04 am
PM

What is there left to say on the Fed?

PM

He might well ask

PM

It is not the start of tightening (September 2014). It is not "lift-off" (this is not Thunderbirds. No rocket-like trajectories are involved). It is a hike in rates, probably with a dissent or two.

11:04 am
PM

What of the future? Yellen is likely to say that the slow path of tightening will be "data dependent". What does that mean? A word means exactly what she wants it to mean, nothing more, nothing less. Markets can interpret "data dependent" to mean whatever they like.
Several Fed speakers have been at pains to indicate that the fabled "dot" forecasts are a reasonable indication of what a "slow" pace of tightening might look like. Looking at the revised dot forecasts may therefore be helpful.
Bank of England governor Carney has been saying that there is no rush for the UK to follow the US. UK labour data comes out today. The Euro area offers final November CPI and some business sentiment data.

PM

Might see if Paul can come on here in the new year

PM

Have a chat about the state of the world

11:06 am
PM

Boncoeur -- yes, we can look at a few single stock situs.

undefined
PM

We could start with Pearson

11:06 am
PM

Pearson plc is no longer the parent company of the Financial Times, publisher of FT Alphaville.

PM

Exane shaken a few bears this morning

BE

(For Boncoeur, go here: http://ftalphavill...e-mistake-of-1998/ ..... There's quite a lot of content on AV other than what we type each morning ... )

11:07 am
PM

gratuitously

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 734.50, up 27.5 (+3.89%), High: 746.50, Low: 722.50, Volume: 2.06m
BE

Let me get the Exane argument up.

11:08 am
BE

.... when it loads. Sorry, my computer's on minimal functionality this morning.

BE

Took four minutes to open a Chrome window.

BE

Right, here we are. Things are bad, but not that bad ....

11:10 am
BE

BE

It's on that template because it's one of Exane's "Christmas crackers"

BE

We appreciate how busy things get at year end, as the countdown to the festive season
begins and investor positioning is at the forefront of everyone’s minds. In time-honoured
tradition, we present you with some intriguing thoughts and ideas for 2016, our Christmas
Crackers.
With a new Chairman taking the helm of Pearson on January 1, 2016, what better moment
to make some New Year Resolutions? Sydney Taurel has more than his fair share of
turkey on his plate. We think he should be focusing on the choice morsels and offloading
the gristle. Join us as we carve deeply into what has become a rather ungainly, flightless
bird and see why we think it could take wing again from 2017.
The holidays are also time for a little fun…
What do the royal family play at Christmas instead of musical chairs? Game of Thrones.

11:10 am
BE

And so on .....

PM

omg smile omg smile omg smile

BE

But let's get to the actual upgrade.

11:11 am
PM

Are they serious?

BE

Yeah, they do this every year. Bit of knockabout fun, mixed with ..... a stock call.

BE

Make of that stock call what you will.

11:12 am
BE

Risks of further earnings downgrades are real but seem discounted by an all-time low valuation.
We are hopeful the new Chairman will lead a profound refocussing of the group with better capital allocation. Cyclical and structural headwinds should ease from 2017.We upgrade to Outperform
A new chairman arrives
Sydney Taurel brings a wealth of experience that will certainly please shareholders. His immediate task will be to restore credibility after the stock’s 45% plunge in the last six months. We are hopeful of seeing two positive developments.
A refocussing of the asset mix – Capital allocation to targeted acquisitions and buybacks
Pearson’s attempt to be ‘everything everywhere’ in education has failed. We believe it needs to refocus away from local language publishing, school testing and low-efficacy content towards instructional materials with proven efficacy, digital learning support services and direct delivery of education in countries with solid demographics/poor public education systems. Targeted acquisitions could help. Management also ought to restore confidence with inexpensive buybacks. The perfect storm of 2015 and 2016 should blow over in 2017 Pearson’s recent commercial performance is mixed and we see no relief in 2016. We are below the EPS consensus by 5% on 2016e and 7% on 2017e but further consensus downgrades already seem discounted in the share price. Headwinds should abate in 2017 as the education policy reforms ease, US enrolment benefits from the move to free college tuition and with positive structural drivers continuing to offset the negative pressure.
Near-term risks remain but the stock looks oversold; we brave the cold and upgrade
The share is on all-time relative lows at 11x P/E16e and 7% yield. On our bear case scenario, the
stock would trade on 13.5x P/E 16e and a 3.7% yield. Could it be the end of the world for Pearson and not for its peers? We think not and turn buyers in anticipation of a profound refocusing, a stable dividend and a return to growth in 2017. Applying peer sales multiples yields 50% upside.

PM

They think the new chairman is going to swan in and simply shrink the business -- dada

PM

Yes, they are going to fire a lot of people

PM

It's 14 % across the board, not 15%

BE

BE

Meh, whatever. It was a good day to upgrade a bombed-out stock. Not much more to say really.

PM

Beer and cash handling and structurally challenged corporate education businesses

undefined
11:18 am
BE

Supergroup already mentioned on the right.

PM

Interims here

BE

Some criticism of Liberum's downgrade yesterday, which I'd suggest rather misunderstands the research.

11:20 am
BE

Basically, we're quite early in the Supergroup reinvention story. These results are okay in that context but the stuff that Liberum was talking about -- sharp discounting, excess stock, stiff competition -- doesn't change.

BE

Let me get Canaccord

BE

SuperGroup has reported a 54% increase in underlying PBT to £19.3m, slightly ahead
of our £19.0m forecast and consensus of £18.5m. This was driven by the combination
of strong (pre-reported) sales growth (+22.3% at group level), a gross margin increase of
110bps (reflecting a better than guided underlying increase of around 45bps, together
with a positive mix benefit from strong Retail sales growth of 31%, LFL +17.2%) and
operational gearing benefits, with underlying operating margin up 180bps to 7.6%.
Excluding the operating loss of £2.4m in the acquired North American business,
underlying PBT increased by just under 75% to £21.7m.
On a divisional basis, Retail operating profit increased 36.4% to £19.1m, with operating
margin up 50bps to 11.1% (or 12.0%, +140bps excluding North American losses). E-
commerce growth continued the strength of H2FY15, with almost 80% yoy growth, now
accounting for 19.2% of Retail revenue (vs 13.9% in H1 last year), with physical stores
also delivering positive LFL sales (we estimate of low single digits). Wholesale sales
grew just under 8%, with operating profit up 40% to £28.4m, with a 790bps increase in
operating margin to 34.4%. This benefited from a higher proportion of full price sales,
combined with increased franchise fee income from continued growth in that network.
Net cash increased to £80m (vs £66.6m), benefiting from a working capital inflow,
as well as higher profits. The group also declared a maiden interim forecast of 6.2p,
implying pro forma cover of 3.2x last year, and we have raised dividends to reflect this.

11:21 am
BE

Impact on our view
It should be remembered that SuperGroup is only in the early stages of delivery of the
strategy it laid out in March. The group has made very good progress on many fronts, but
there remains much to do, with future benefits yet to accrue. With our forecasts slightly
below consensus, we have raised our PBT (EPS and dividend) estimates on the basis
primarily of increased gross margin guidance (to +40bps to 60bps for FY16, from 0 to
+30bps previously). This outweighs a small increase to North America loss guidance for
this year and next (due only to a slightly slower realisation of the Retail turnaround) and
normalisation of variable (ie bonus/incentivisation) pay. EPS growth also benefits from
lower tax rate guidance to our previous forecasts. Capex has also been guided £10m higher
for FY16 to £45m, reflecting investment in retail space, US and European warehousing and
additional Head Office space in Cheltenham, but should return to around £35m thereafter.
Valuation
At last night's close the shares were trading on a cal 15 PER of 23.2x falling to 19.8x for
cal16. The equivalent EV/EBITDA ratios stood at 11.6x and 9.9x respectively. The PER
rating reflects a warranted premium to the sector given the earnings growth profile that
we are forecasting on the back of international brand growth. We maintain our 1847p
target price (supported by our adjusted Quest ® valuation, which assumes 15% real
capital growth and a three-year fade delay to CFROA and growth).

BE

And to reiterate that point, here's Liberum's take .....

BE

(SGP LN) PBT of £19m, a touch ahead of expecations (Liberum £18m) after what was, as expected, a strong first half. We already knew that Retail LFL sales grew 17% and the margins would be strong because of a change in sales mix. The outlook stattement says nothing useful. "In the near-term, our main focus is to deliver a successful peak trading period." No comments on current trading or how likely it is that they will hit FY profits. Remember that H2 drives 75% of FY profits so it is all to play for, over Christmas especially, and the reason behind our downgrade yesterday is that the market is getting much more competitive and that both SuperGroup and the rest of the high street have excess stock.

11:22 am
BE

So, yeah, if Supergroup had had a bad August it would've warned in October, as it did last year.

PM

People really buying into the "underlying" side of this story

PM

Give the price this morning

11:23 am
SuperGroup PLC (SGP:LSE): Last: 1,656, up 140.08 (+9.24%), High: 1,725, Low: 1,616, Volume: 300.60k
PM

Underlying is defined as reported results adjusted to reflect the impact of exceptional items and re-measurements (and the related income tax where appropriate). The Directors believe that the underlying results provide additional guidance to statutory measures to help understand the performance of the Group.

BE

The greater worry is that it's heading into Christmas with what looks like a lot of stuff to clear.

11:24 am
BE

There's nothing in today's statement to suggest that's going to end happily. Though I accept the market seems chilled, and good luck to the market.

undefined
BE

On Shire, I've not heard a story.

11:25 am
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,333, up 151 (+3.61%), High: 4,350, Low: 4,212, Volume: 550.13k
BE

Including this Intercept Pharmaceuticals one, that looks incrementally interesting rather than share-price significant.

BE

What I can say is that there are a couple of sellside pushes.

11:26 am
BE

None saying what we don't know already, but I guess it helps. Here's Leerink.

BE

• Bottom Line: We continue to see SHPG as a compelling investment
opportunity given the recent pullback. This afternoon we had an
opportunity to speak with CEO Flemming Ornskov and CFO Jeff Poulton
about growing investor concerns around fit/rationale of a BXLT-SHPG
combination. Overall, we found mgmt feedback assuring that the
company will only pursue BXLT through a transaction structure that
is friendly to SHPG shareholders, and that the company “will not wait
around forever” if a deal cannot be consummated. We continue to believe
the most likely scenarios are (1) a revised offer, at a slightly higher price,
using significant cash component translating to a deal that is at least
15-20% accretive; or (2) SHPG walks away early next year – under this
scenario, we’d envision SHPG shares up at least ~20%. In our view,
recent developments around lifitegrast (dry eye) have not been reflected
in the valuation and mid-2016 Ph. 2b data for premiplex (retinopathy of
prematurity) are not priced into the stock, both sources of upside.

BE

• Mgmt remains committed to BXLT deal, but only if a shareholder
friendly deal structure can be agreed upon. Regarding capital
allocation and M&A, we agree with Dr. Ornskov that the market fears
around SHPG deploying a massive increase in equity to match/exceed
prior deal EV are overdone. While mgmt is not in a position to discuss
any specifics, it is our strong sense that mgmt can pursue alternative
financing options (beyond just increasing stock) in a way to make the deal
highly accretive to SHPG shareholders. As for investor concerns around
the durability of BXLT’s hemophilia A franchise with emerging pipeline
threats, the CEO commented: (1) he firmly expects hemophilia A market
to be a sticky marketplace, likely to evolve into a more fragmented space
and eventual loss of some BXLT share to pipeline programs like ROG’s
ACE910 already built into SHPG’s deal model. This is consistent with
recent feedback we've heard from MEDACorp hematology specialists; (2)
pipeline agents like Vonvendi for Von Willebrand disease viewed as an
underappreciated asset by the market.

11:27 am
BE

But BXLT M&A pursuit is not an indefinite process. According to Dr.
Ornskov, SHPG will not stand still nor will it wait around forever on the
BXLT deal. SHPG announced a major deal in DYAX (MP) subsequent to
its initial BXLT overture and mgmt continues to seek M&A alternatives.
• Lifitegrast, a blockbuster product lost in the shuffle due to BXLT
concerns. SHPG plans to file lifitegrast for dry eye in 1Q16 and we
believe the product could be on the market by 3Q16. We see lifitegrast’s
onset of action, stat sig at day 14, as a major point of differentiation
vs. AGN’s Restasis. Given the favorable p-value (0.0001) and large
number of pts (n=711) we believe lifitegrast will have a differentiated label
that includes (1) dramatically faster onset of action; and (2) a symptom
improvement label claim. SHPG anticipates more detailed data will be
presented at upcoming major medical meetings.

BE

And Cowen & Co.

BE

SHPG is in the process – via Natpara and now a likely H2:16 Lifitegrast launch – of
introducing $2.0-3.0B in new revenue to complement its current $6.5B portfolio. And
the purchase of Dyax provides another likely $2B program, extending the duration of
its HAE franchise. Although Baxalta remains controversial, we believe the risks are
now well factored, while the benefits are completely discounted.

11:28 am
BE

(Cowen & Co push Shire every other day, so don't get too excited here.)

BE

Shire is currently a $6.5B annualized revenue company, which is in the process of
launching what we believe will ultimately be a $750MM+ long-duration Natpara, and
could soon be in a position to launch a $2B+ long-duration Lifitegrast in H2:2016.
With the Dyax purchase, it appears that Shire should now also be in a position to
launch a potential $2B long-duration, DX-2930, which should more than offset our
already modeled declining Cinryze revenues (due to our previous anticipation of the
potential DX-2930 launch). In addition to this combined potential $2.0-3.0B in near-
term new product revenue, we believe that there still remains an under-appreciation
of the potential for even more aggressive business development (with or without
Baxalta) given Shire's current balance sheet leverage (even factoring the recent
Dyax acquisition) of $7-10B to further augment the portfolio with other long-duration
orphan asset purchases. To state it simply, this would be one of the highest quality
organic/inorganic hybrid growth models in the space, trading at blended 2017/2018
multiples that more closely represent a value stock, but with modest leverage and in
an advantaged position to purchase very high-quality orphan assets.

BE

Importantly, as investor attention remains focused on the Baxalta approach, we
believe that with or without it, the valuation more than reflects many of the worst-case
concerns. In the scenario that the Baxalta transaction is agreed upon, Shire would
be set to achieve substantial and immediate revenue/earnings diversification with
an expanded balance sheet (given the preponderance of equity) and significantly
enhanced cash flows to even more aggressively pursue additional orphan assets. And
we believe the potential proforma financials at this point reflect a feverish level of
pessimism. Specifically, our proforma SHPG/BXLT 2017 earnings would reach $16.05
(+10% accretive or +$1.65), rising to $20.45 in 2018 (+20% accretive or +$3.15),
and $24.35 in 2019 (+25% accretive or +$4.85).
This would mean that at the current
SHPG trading levels of $190 would equate to 11-12x the 2017 proforma estimates, and
9-10x the proforma 2018 figures
. And all of our analysis from a duration perspective
reflects significant pressure from the competitive Roche product ACE910, with
steep degradation to the Advate/Adynovate and Feiba franchises assumed – and
yet we believe the transaction would still make sense. The bottom-line is if there
is perceived value in a Allergan/Valeant model, then Shire – either standalone or
via the combination with Baxalta – provides higher quality organic growth (given
our conviction in Lifitegrast and the pipeline) with a cleaner balance sheet that will
allow for more thoughtful and value-creating business development at a compelling
valuation. And importantly, this would all be while remaining an innovative company
with likely additional internal pipeline contribution that is currently receiving little-
to-no credit. At the current valuation, this hybrid model looks like one of the most
compelling in our space.

11:29 am
BE

Target $325 against a $190-ish current price on the ADRs.

PM

Welcome to ML

PM

hehehe

11:30 am
BE

11:32 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 213.85, up 4.35 (+2.08%), High: 213.95, Low: 209.30, Volume: 16.05m
BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3uEE85JAG

11:33 am
BE

Message in investor meetings seems to be "door remains open", in tone if not in phrasing.

BE

"Neither side is pushing the other away, which is interesting in itself, and even their language seems similar," says one shareholder.

BE

And "The deal depends on the valuation between Vodafone and Liberty narrowing . . . more simply the share price of Vodafone has to go up a fair bit to make it work," says one financier close to Vod.

11:35 am
BE

Dan's not the type to take wild fliers so the piece deserves a careful read.

BE

Anyway, in terms of telcos .....

BE

..... Deutsche Bank pushing Vod this morning in its 2016 sector preview.

11:36 am
BE

Organic growth continues to improve , project Spring capex falls in Fy16/17, premium div. re-covered

BE

But the M&A section is clearle the more interesting bit.

BE

We view that there were two main drivers of Telco out-performance, hopes for
consolidation and improving top line trends. Whilst a number of deals were
announced (BT+EE, O2+3, Wind+3) hopes that the European authorities would
wave through these mergers with limited remedies were dealt a blow in
September on collapse of the deal to merge TeliaSonera and Telenor assets in
Denmark).
More consolidation an upside, not a necessary precursor to sector performance
The dip in telco shares and sentiment on the sector post cancelation of the
Denmark deal was material. Our note “Growth re-rating further to run, though
EM still drags” dated 16 September 2015 however flagged that the event was
more of a removal of a tailwind than headwind and the sector has recovered.
We also note that widening credit spreads which compounded the difficulties
for Altice financing the acquisition of CVC also hit confidence on the sector,
though we note that European Telcos as a whole tend to do well, relatively, at
times of widening credit spreads.

11:37 am
BE

We remind that remedies on mergers are designed to prevent a diminution in
consumer price competition but still produce benefits for the merging parties,
such as lower costs. Regulators are seeking new powers to regulate ‘tight
oligopolies’ to ensure that consolidation does not result in a negative outcome
for consumers.
We assume the O2-3 and Wind-3 deals to go through albeit with significant
remedies up to and including the effective establishment of a fourth operator
in each market. Such a scenario should not be worse than the status quo at
least, but we note that in the UK, a simultaneous push by BT into mobile for
the first time could result in an increase in competition in a market that was
somewhat resilient to the travails of other European markets.

BE

Regardless of consolidation European Telco revenue trends are improving
chiefly driven by mobile, post subsidence of four simultaneous drags on
growth: the economy, regulation, competition (exacerbated by weak private
consumption and facilitated by regulation) and lack of secular growth (e.g.
demand for mobile data has been depressed in part due to economic factors
but also lower network investment than in other regions). We see upside risk
to growth particularly from mobile where our expectations have been moving
higher

BE

So that's that.

11:38 am
undefined
BE

Speaking of Deutsche .....

BE

Want today's Anglo American downgrades?

11:39 am
BE

DB go to "hold". Having been buyers. They were buyers is what I'm saying.

BE

And it's the usual argument. Anglo's doing too little, and probably can't do it anyway.

BE

Management presented the updated strategy at its recent Investor Day as a
point of no return. Our concern is not the strategy but the (at least initial) lack
of apparent urgency around it. There was no acceleration in near term cost-out
guidance, the disposal of phosphates and niobium, and the dividend
suspension were expected and commentary suggested progress through the
year and into 2017 on cost-out and disposals. We do not believe this to be
enough in current circumstances. Having crossed the Rubicon, it is not clear
that management is marching onto Rome. We downgrade to Hold awaiting
evidence of urgency.

11:39 am
BE

CEO Mr. Cutifani has sought to manage through building consensus and
bringing the organization with him. Whilst this is commendable, after two
years of leaving drinks, the danger is the resulting rate of progress is delivering
the opposite. The organization needs closure on the past and to move on with
the new, not another transition period over 18 months. The streamlining of the
portfolio is not with the benefit of hindsight but something the market has
repeatedly called for. And whilst additional disposals of quality assets may not
be appealing, management, in our view, is now left with little choice.

BE

Management guided to US$(1bn) of FCF at spot for 2016, implying 2017 FCF
would be ~US$1bn. Planned disposals could reduce debt by US$2bn, but we
believe a doubling of this is needed along with faster cost-out progress. At
spot, to regain control of the balance sheet, a rights issue is required. Net debt
of US$10bn on DBe would leave 2017E net debt/EBITDA (exc. S. Africa) at 3x.

BE

Debt reduction should come from the disposal of assets outside of South
Africa –there is no net debt in SA and all repatriation is required to be equal or
less than the plc dividend). In addition to niobium, phosphates and the Chagres
smelter, bids should be sought for nickel, Cerrejon and Minas Rio. The Board,
under pressure from shareholders should, we believe, force management to
commit to a clearer & more urgent timeframe at the 16 February update.

11:40 am
BE

Our NPV drops following our 1Q16 commodity review. We believe the market
now needs to see not just the details of the new strategy and timeframe, but
actual delivery. We are cognisant of the fundamental upside should we see
this, and the downside risks given the balance sheet should we not. TP is
based on a 0.7x multiple on the asset valuation (was 0.8x).

BE

And as mentioned on the right previously, SocGen is arguing for an Anglo cash call

BE

Though one can debate whether Anglo preserving its investment-grade rating actually matters.

11:41 am
BE

We remain concerned about weak FCF generation. Our ‘spot’ EBITDA comes in
at $3.5bn, i.e. in line with the figure given by AA at its IR day last week. As we forecast
negative FCF next year and positive FCF in FY17, absolute net debt at c.$14bn is a real
concern to us, implying c.4.0x FY16e net debt to spot EBITDA before any asset disposals.
We have revised down our base-case scenario earnings assumptions to reflect lower commodity prices. We have also mostly taken on board the initiatives announced by AA last week. We are now looking for EPS of $0.86 for 2015e (was $1.02), $0.35 for 2016e ($0.73) and $0.59 for 2017e ($0.98).

BE

Inputting our new estimates, we cut our rating to Sell (was Hold) and our target price to 250p (was 530p). We still value the stock using a combination of a blended NPV (WACC 8.6%) and 5.5x EV/EBITDA (vs 10y average of 6.0x) We base our TP on the weighted average of our base-case scenario (60% was 70%) and a ‘spot’ scenario (40% vs 30%). In our ‘spot’ scenario we assume AA makes a $1.7bn rights issue . With fundamentals still weakening and -11% 12m projected TSR (zero DPS), we are sellers of the stock.

BE

As noted in the paper overnight, Auto Trader's now bigger than Anglo by market cap.

11:42 am
BE

As is Rightmove.

BE

Which makes a $1.7bn cash call really rather dilutive.

BE

(@Pseudonym: yup. Market cap, not EV.)

BE

So Home24 and Westwing seem to be below expectations. I've no idea what these are, so can't really comment.

BE

Portfolio value of €6.1bn is basically flat, €1.2bn cash at holding level

11:51 am
BE

Caz is still undecided here.

BE

Reminder of several key targets that the company believes it can be
measured against: 1) Performance: Combined EBITDA losses for Proven
Winners to peak in 2015 (though the peak will differ amongst companies);
2) Path to Profitability: Three Proven Winners to reach break-even at group
level by Q4 17; 3) Capital Requirement: No dilutive capital issuance in the
next three years at group level; 4) Value Crystallisation: Assuming a
‘normal’ equity capital markets environment, one Proven Winner will go
public within the next 18 months; 5) Portfolio of Companies: In the next 18
mths, one new Company will reach Proven Winner status; 6) Pipeline:
Identification of new highly attractive models; 7) Transparency: Move to
Prime Standard within the next 12 months; 8) M&A: No significant M&A
transaction.
 New Chairman of Supervisory Board: The company also announced
today that Dr Marcus Englert will become the Chairman of the Supervisory

Rocket’s 3q update is reassuringly consistent with strategy of
delivering strong growth with an increasing focus on profitability. With
two exceptions, strong growth continues and we expect profitability to
accelerate in 2016 which underpins valuation and Rocket’s strong cash
position, core features of our OW rating.
With the exception of Westwing and Jabong (4.5% of our target valuation),
Rocket’s 3q results are in-line with our expectations with improving
profitability a developing trend. Group GMV growth in the first 9 months is
+120% (it was 142% in H115) and the margin improved from (33)% to (29)%.
We highlight Global Fashion Group (blended growth +71% in 9m), Lazada
(+225%), the Food businesses, Home 24 and Jumia (GMV +265%) as
businesses developing strongly. Rocket management reiterates all key targets
made at the recent investor day including reducing cash burn, equity raising
and value crystallization.

BE

In the last 3 months Rocket’s Last Portfolio Valuation (LPV) has
remained unchanged at €7.2bn/ €44 per share, with €4.6bn derived
from its 13 “proven winners.” This represents a significant premium to the
prevailing share price (€30) with an uplift in Food delivery/ preparation the key
changes since January. Our target valuation has higher valuations at Global
Fashion Group and Lazada in particular which both performed strongly in 3q.
In particular we note that both Namshi (MENA) & Lamoda (Russia) are now
close to break even, with Dafiti (Brazil) seeing accelerated trading in 3q to over
60%. Combined GFG is set to deliver revenues of ~€1bn in 2015. Lazada has
further cemented its leading position in eCommerce across SE Asia with GMV
of $1.5bn in 2015, which we believe justifies a significant uplift (€90m to
€213m) in EBITDA losses in 9M.
In the context of a more recent deterioration in the external funding and
market environment, especially in the US, Rocket’s €1bn of net cash at the
Holdco level, target of investing sub €300m pa and our forecast of improved
margins from 2015 implies Rocket remains well funded with ~$1bn of gross
cash in 2018. After a tough and busy 2015, this also suggests that Rocket has
no need/ plan to raise additional equity (dilutive) for at least 3 years.

BE

It’s unclear, however, what would satisfy the DoJ as it hasn’t given any indication to what their concerns are, nor suggested what remedies would alleviate such concerns. The positive is that the DoJ didn’t block the merger through litigation, suggesting it believes there could be a resolution. Furthermore, this should ultimately be a stepping-off point to attain clarity from the DoJ regarding its concerns and suggested remedies. On the other hand, it is hard to ignore the defiant tone in HAL’s statement that both HAL and BHI “strongly believe that the divestiture package is more than sufficient”, which could be interpreted as HAL laying the groundwork for litigation, though we believe HAL will continue to seek an agreement before resorting to litigation. BHI’s risk arb spread increased only ~100bp today to ~23% at the close as the market was already fairly concerned about anti-competitive approvals, viewing litigation as possible, if not likely. With no timetable for the DoJ to make a decision, the next date to watch is January 12th when the European Commission is scheduled to make its ruling.

11:59 am
BE

Tungsten interim results are well below expectations. While revenue for the interim period of £13.1m is up 28.4%, full year expectations assumed 38.3% growth but are being reduced again in the company’s outlook to £27.5m. We note that 2016 revenue expectations were gradually reduced from £85.9m earlier this year. The EBITDA loss of £9.5m is also greater than expected and the company is managing the current expected £13.0m loss for the full year to no more than £19.0m. While this is clearly disappointing versus the expectations, it is likely not a massive surprise given the share price decline from the 80p level after the full year results in July to 41p yesterday. There has also been a considerable level of short interest of 5.2% so the shares have been volatile already this morning.

The good news is appears the company is close (exclusivity agreement) to selling off the bank it acquired July 2014 to an unnamed buyer. Although no price has yet been disclosed, the process will take PRA approval which will likely be six to twelve months. This would release precious cash that was being tied up by regulatory requirements. The Group's cash position is expected to be at least £8m excluding the cash in Tungsten Bank, or no less than £33m including cash currently held in the Bank by the end of FY’16 so we see no significant cash constraints in the near future assuming the sale goes through.

Progress with financing has been minimal and the on-boarding of new suppliers has not been as good as expected. We plan to gain more insight on the company’s conference call this morning on these topics.

While Tungsten is not expected to be generating profits until 2018, it trades on quite a low multiple of sales when cash is excluded. The company’s market capitalisation of £51.4m includes £33.7m of cash (the majority restricted but expected to be released within twelve months) and on this basis trade at 0.6x EV/Sales.

12:00 pm
BE

EBITDA and FCF are on improving trends. EBITDA loss improved to £9.5m in H1 FY16 from £13.2m in H1 FY15. Similarly, Equity FCF loss improved to £9.6m from £15.4m in H2 FY15 and £17.2m in H1 FY15. EBITDA and FCF should improve further: H1 FY16 EBITDA loss of £9.5m includes £2.4m of one-off costs and approximately £1m of fixed costs in Tungsten Bank that should be eliminated with the sale of the bank. Therefore, 'underlying' EBITDA loss was £6.1m in H1 FY16. Free cash outflow tracks EBITDA closely, at £1.1m per month and about £0.9m per month excluding losses from the bank itself. As a result, we conservatively expect net cash including Tungsten Bank to fall to £33m by FYE16 from £39.7 at the end of H1 FY16.

Tungsten plans to reach EBITDA breakeven by the end of FY17. Going forward costs and expenses are not expected to rise while revenues continue to rise, driven by supplier and buyer additions, price increases, increased automation of onboarding and increased momentum in Tungsten Early Payment and ancillary services, including analytics.

BE

H1 FY16 'Underlying' EBITDA of £6.1m and free cash outflow of approximately £0.9m per month excluding Tungsten Bank compare favourably against net cash, excluding cash in Tungsten Bank, of £15.9m plus an expected consideration of approximately £30m from the sale of Tungsten Bank. In comparison, Tungsten's market cap is £51m, which implies limited value for the business itself. We lower our SoTP target price from 84p to 76p (Tungsten Early Payment 21p; Tungsten Network 65p; central costs -37p; FY16 net cash 26p).
